Title.evidence: Comparison of Outcomes of Antibiotic Drugs and Appendectomy: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: The CODA trial was a multicenter RCT conducted in 25 US medical centers, enrolling participants from May 3, 2016, to February 5, 2020.

Participants.evidence: Eligible adults with appendicitis were randomised to receive either appendectomy or antibiotics.

Intervention.evidence: Eligible adults with appendicitis were randomised to receive either appendectomy or antibiotics.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to compare outcomes between participants in the CODA randomised controlled trial (RCT) and a parallel cohort study of participants who self-selected treatment.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of appendectomy within 30 days, with all participants followed for at least one year.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 1094 participants were randomised (appendectomy: 547, antibiotics: 547), and 510 were in the self-selection cohort (appendectomy: 253, antibiotics: 257).

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 1094 participants were randomised (appendectomy: 547, antibiotics: 547), and 510 were in the self-selection cohort (appendectomy: 253, antibiotics: 257).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The rate of appendectomy by 30 days was 15.3% in the self-selection antibiotics group and 19.2% in the randomised antibiotics group (difference, 3.9%; 95% CI, −1.7% to 9.5%).

Harms.evidence: No significant differences in adverse events were reported between groups.
